description:
This changes the implementation of the scale callback to use matplotlib's AnchoredSizeBar artist. It also fixes some other issues related to how the scale bar is scaled.

Right now we don't attempt to draw a scale bar if the x and y limits aren't identical.  This is not necessary, instead we should only bail from drawing the scale bar if the *scaling* of the x and y axes are different.  This is encoded in the `_aspect` attribute of the `WindowPlotMPL` objects, which itself can be set via the `aspect` keyword argument of any of the `PlotWindow` class initializers. I've adjusted the check to be based on the aspect ratio. Since we weren't passing the plot aspect ratio to callbacks until now, I've gone ahead and added the `aspect` attribute to the `CallbackWrapper`.

In addition, now that we're not using the text and line plot callbacks under the hood, I've replaced the dictionaries controlling their properties with a single dictionary that gets passed to `AnchoredSizeBar`. This callback hasn't been in a release yet, so I don't need to formally deprecate things.

I'd love feedback on these changes.  The main improvement is that the scale bar can now be drawn with an inset box, which makes it much easier to see when drawn on top of a plot that has lots of structure.

Quick example:


```
#!python

slc.annotate_scale(size_bar_args=dict(pad=0.75, sep=5, borderpad=0.5, frameon=True, color='k'))
```


![galaxy0030_Slice_x_density.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/584938296-galaxy0030_Slice_x_density.png)
title: annotate_scale improvements

content.raw: ping @chummels
content.html: ping Cameron Hummels

content.raw: Care was taken in creating these positions to have the scale bar align with the `annotate_timescale()` output, since these will often be used in concert.  Is there a way to assure these will be aligned using the new method?
content.html: Care was taken in creating these positions to have the scale bar align with the annotate_timescale() output, since these will often be used in concert. Is there a way to assure these will be aligned using the new method?

content.raw:
In order to retain consistency with the other callbacks for assuring that the font properties of the callback are in line with those of the overall plot, the preferred method is something like this:

```
#!python

       label = plot._axes.text(x, y, self.text, transform=self.transform,
                                bbox=self.inset_box_args, **kwargs)
        self._set_font_properties(plot, [label], **kwargs)
```

Or you can see the end of the `TextLabelCallback` for an example.
content.html:
In order to retain consistency with the other callbacks for assuring that the font properties of the callback are in line with those of the overall plot, the preferred method is something like this:

       label = plot._axes.text(x, y, self.text, transform=self.transform,
                                bbox=self.inset_box_args, **kwargs)
        self._set_font_properties(plot, [label], **kwargs)

Or you can see the end of the TextLabelCallback for an example.

content.html: Quick correction that isn't your fault: timestamp -> scale

content.raw:
Hey @ngoldbaum , overall this looks like an improvement in terms of simplifying the scale callback.  Nice job!  A couple of things:

It doesn't look like the `pos` kwarg works anymore for specifying an arbitrary location where you can put the scale callback.  Previously, if you specified it (along with the `coord_system` kwarg) you could put the scale wherever you wanted.  All of the coordinate sanitization took place inside the `LinePlotCallback` and the `TextLabelCallback`, which is probably how you missed it here.  I think now you can only put the scale callback in one of the pre-ordained positions in the corners (ie `loc`= [0,10]).  Can we make the `AnchoredSizeBar` work with an arbitrary position (and arbitrary coord system) using the machinery I built for doing this?

I mentioned below about the `font_properties` issue for consistency with other callbacks to assure that the font matches that of the overall plot.  An additional concern here is whether or not we can set all of the font properties in the `AnchoredSizeBar` the way we can in the `TextLabelCallback` since the `text_args` kwarg is getting subsumed into the `size_bar_args`.  Can we still?

Since the `annotate_scale()` and `annotate_timestamp()`get used together often, I worked hard to make sure they would work well in unison.  This meant I tried to get their default positions aligned well.  I'm concerned that this PR altered these this alignment by placing the scalebar at the MPL default positions (see http://i.imgur.com/kwIAntj.png for the default `annotate_scale()` and `annotate_timestamp()` with this PR).  Suggestions?  Maybe we can use the same MPL positions with the `annotate_timestamp()` callback so that plots generated using both don't look misaligned?  

It looks like something is wrong with the `draw_inset_box` kwarg with this PR.  When I set it and use the defaults, I get this: http://i.imgur.com/PAx8sVr.png .  I guess we just need to change the default size_bar_args?  Is it possible to match the `annotate_timestamp()` inset box so that they match colors, size, opacity?

I wish I'd known about this MPL class when I wrote the scale callback, as it would've saved this upgrade.  Thanks for doing this, though.  It looks like a move toward the FUTURE.
content.html:
Hey Nathan Goldbaum , overall this looks like an improvement in terms of simplifying the scale callback. Nice job! A couple of things:

It doesn't look like the pos kwarg works anymore for specifying an arbitrary location where you can put the scale callback. Previously, if you specified it (along with the coord_system kwarg) you could put the scale wherever you wanted. All of the coordinate sanitization took place inside the LinePlotCallback and the TextLabelCallback, which is probably how you missed it here. I think now you can only put the scale callback in one of the pre-ordained positions in the corners (ie loc= [0,10]). Can we make the AnchoredSizeBar work with an arbitrary position (and arbitrary coord system) using the machinery I built for doing this?

I mentioned below about the font_properties issue for consistency with other callbacks to assure that the font matches that of the overall plot. An additional concern here is whether or not we can set all of the font properties in the AnchoredSizeBar the way we can in the TextLabelCallback since the text_args kwarg is getting subsumed into the size_bar_args. Can we still?

Since the annotate_scale() and annotate_timestamp()get used together often, I worked hard to make sure they would work well in unison. This meant I tried to get their default positions aligned well. I'm concerned that this PR altered these this alignment by placing the scalebar at the MPL default positions (see http://i.imgur.com/kwIAntj.png for the default annotate_scale() and annotate_timestamp() with this PR). Suggestions? Maybe we can use the same MPL positions with the annotate_timestamp() callback so that plots generated using both don't look misaligned?

It looks like something is wrong with the draw_inset_box kwarg with this PR. When I set it and use the defaults, I get this: http://i.imgur.com/PAx8sVr.png . I guess we just need to change the default size_bar_args? Is it possible to match the annotate_timestamp() inset box so that they match colors, size, opacity?

I wish I'd known about this MPL class when I wrote the scale callback, as it would've saved this upgrade. Thanks for doing this, though. It looks like a move toward the FUTURE.

content.raw: Unfortunately the `AnchoredSizeBar` doesn't subscribe to the API that `_set_font_properties` assumes, so I can't use that function. Fortunately `AnchoredSizeBar` takes a `FontProperties` instance as a keyword argument to its initializer, so It works out to the same thing.
content.html: Unfortunately the AnchoredSizeBar doesn't subscribe to the API that _set_font_properties assumes, so I can't use that function. Fortunately AnchoredSizeBar takes a FontProperties instance as a keyword argument to its initializer, so It works out to the same thing.

content.raw:
I visually double checked on a square plot and it the locations are all consistent.  The matplotlib docs claim that `loc` can be a 2-tuple, but that doesn't seem to work for `AnchoredSizeBar`.

Are you ok with the scale bar being locked to one of the locations allowed by matplotlib's `loc` codes? See http://matplotlib.org/api/pyplot_api.html#matplotlib.pyplot.legend

It also looks like matplotlib `Text` objects can't be placed by a `loc` code, so I don't think I can fully reconcile this with the timestamp callback.
content.html:
I visually double checked on a square plot and it the locations are all consistent. The matplotlib docs claim that loc can be a 2-tuple, but that doesn't seem to work for AnchoredSizeBar.

Are you ok with the scale bar being locked to one of the locations allowed by matplotlib's loc codes? See http://matplotlib.org/api/pyplot_api.html#matplotlib.pyplot.legend

It also looks like matplotlib Text objects can't be placed by a loc code, so I don't think I can fully reconcile this with the timestamp callback.

content.raw:
OK, I think all of these concerns should be addressed, including my responses inline below.

With the current version of this PR, the default inset boxes look like this: http://i.imgur.com/weTqYtr.png

content.raw:
Nice--you matched the old inset box characteristics.  Looks good.  A couple of docstrings things, but first.

One thing that just dawned on me about the legend-style-only placement of the scale callback is that it is going to look weird for movies where the scale is changing, because it will shift around the position of the text.  It looks good for stand-alone images, but in a movie with a varying lengthscale (e.g. cosmology movies) it looks weird.

Here is an example.  [This script](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5565/) generates [this movie prior to the PR](http://chummels.org/movies/old.mp4), and [this movie with the code from this PR](http://chummels.org/movies/new.mp4).

The way I got around it in the old way was making the position far enough to the left that the scale bar never gets big enough to touch the axis edge.  But I think with the legend-style `loc` settings, it defines the placement of the text to be close to the edge of the axis.  Given that we cannot specify the position manually, I'm not sure how to get around this.  Ideas?  Perhaps by buffering the unit text with enough spaces on the left+right sides that it juts the whole bar out farther from the edge?  But this seems problematic since we don't know how many characters a priori, and we have to do it on both sides to make sure the inset box looks ok ([movie with inset box](http://chummels.org/movies/new_bbox.mp4)).
content.html:
Nice--you matched the old inset box characteristics. Looks good. A couple of docstrings things, but first.

One thing that just dawned on me about the legend-style-only placement of the scale callback is that it is going to look weird for movies where the scale is changing, because it will shift around the position of the text. It looks good for stand-alone images, but in a movie with a varying lengthscale (e.g. cosmology movies) it looks weird.

Here is an example. This script generates this movie prior to the PR, and this movie with the code from this PR.

The way I got around it in the old way was making the position far enough to the left that the scale bar never gets big enough to touch the axis edge. But I think with the legend-style loc settings, it defines the placement of the text to be close to the edge of the axis. Given that we cannot specify the position manually, I'm not sure how to get around this. Ideas? Perhaps by buffering the unit text with enough spaces on the left+right sides that it juts the whole bar out farther from the edge? But this seems problematic since we don't know how many characters a priori, and we have to do it on both sides to make sure the inset box looks ok (movie with inset box).

content.raw: if we're truly not using the `pos` or the `coord_system` kwargs, we should remove them (and references to them) from the docstrings.
content.html: if we're truly not using the pos or the coord_system kwargs, we should remove them (and references to them) from the docstrings.

content.raw: And I suppose remove `pos` and `coord_system` from the function call.
content.html: And I suppose remove pos and coord_system from the function call.

content.raw: I found that a value of 0.0 or 0.05 for `pad` seemed to match the results from `annotate_timestamp()` the best.
content.html: I found that a value of 0.0 or 0.05 for pad seemed to match the results from annotate_timestamp() the best.

content.raw: It also appears from those movies that the scale bar itself is changing its thickness based on its width, which looks a little weird in a movie.  Is there a way to use a fixed thickness instead of a fixed aspect ratio for the line?
content.html: It also appears from those movies that the scale bar itself is changing its thickness based on its width, which looks a little weird in a movie. Is there a way to use a fixed thickness instead of a fixed aspect ratio for the line?

content.raw: After spelunking a bit in the matplotlib internal API I was able to figure out an incantation that allows me to use absolute positioning for the scale bar.  The issue with the scale bar moving around in zoom movies should be fixed.
content.html: After spelunking a bit in the matplotlib internal API I was able to figure out an incantation that allows me to use absolute positioning for the scale bar. The issue with the scale bar moving around in zoom movies should be fixed.

content.raw: I'm now using a fixed height of .01 in normalized axis coordinates.
content.html: I'm now using a fixed height of .01 in normalized axis coordinates.
